trans-unit.source: Determines how a control validates its data when it loses user input focus.
If a user switches focus off of a Windows Forms control, the control will use <xref:System.Windows.Forms.AutoValidate> to determine how to validate its data.

This type of validation is called implicit validation, because it occurs without the application developer having to make an explicit call to <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ContainerControl.Validate%2A> or <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ContainerControl.ValidateChildren%2A>.
The property corresponding to this value will have different defaults based on the type of control.
For more information, see [User Input Validation in Windows Forms](~/docs/framework/winforms/user-input-validation-in-windows-forms.md).

Setting this value will not interfere with explicit calls to <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.ContainerControl.Validate"></xref> or <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.ContainerControl.ValidateChildren"></xref>.
Implicit validation occurs, but if validation fails, focus will still change to the new control.
If validation fails, the <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.Control.Validated"></xref> event will not fire.
Implicit validation occurs when the control loses focus.
The control inherits its <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.AutoValidate"></xref> behavior from its container (such as a form or another control).
If there is no container control, it defaults to <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.AutoValidate.EnablePreventFocusChange"></xref>.
